newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST - UK PPI to weaken as pound stays strong.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - UK PPI to weaken as pound stays strong.

text.p: UK producer output prices remained weak in April as the effects of lower input prices fed through to the factory gate, analysts said on Friday.
The combined pressures of sterling strength and lower oil prices are set to force input prices lower again after a 0.5 percent month-on-month fall in March.
Producer input and output prices are due at 0830 GMT on Monday. A Reuter poll of economists forecast another 0.5 percent drop, leaving them 8.4 percent down year-on-year.
"As input prices continue to set 10-year lows, there is little upward pressure on the output price series," said Ciaran Barr, UK economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell .

He forecast headline output prices to be unchanged in April, taking year-on-year growth down to 0.7 percent. The Reuter poll tipped a marginal, 0.1 percent increase in April output prices and annual inflation of 0.8 percent.
Analysts cited a 2.0 percent rise in the sterling trade-weighted index in April and an 8.0 percent fall in oil prices over the month as bolstering the chances of another fall in input prices.
Though manufacturers would probably swallow some of the reduced input costs by widening margins, analysts said the lack of pipeline price pressure would feed through to the consumer.
"On output prices I think there's a pretty good chance of another downward turn in core output prices," said Jonathan Loynes, analyst at HSBC Markets.

He said the Confederation of British Industry's monthly trends survey pointed to a slight dip in core output prices -- excluding food, drink, tobacco and petrol -- if not this month then next. Loynes expected a fall of 0.4 percent in April.
And while upstream inflationary pressures look subdued, analysts saw the weakness of export demand and price sensitivity of British consumers capping demand-pull effects.
"While manufacturers are keeping some of the benefits of lower costs for themselves, the fragility of demand is forcing them to pass on a large share at the factory gate," said Loynes.
Sluggish demand combined with the strength of the pound is taking its toll on UK exports to key European markets.
In spite of a dramatic plunge by the pound -- more than four pfennigs -- on Thursday, its overall strength means input prices could keep falling.
"The strength of the pound will keep input inflation falling with a drop below minus 10 percent odds on in the couple of months," Loynes said.
